sections.title: Dental bridges in Shoreham-by-Sea
sections.body: A dental bridge replaces one or more missing teeth by supporting a fixed tooth (or teeth) between neighbouring teeth or implants. Suitability depends on the health of the supporting teeth, gum condition, bite forces and the size and position of the gap. We assess the area carefully, because a bridge should feel stable, cleanable and comfortable in the long term. In some cases, an implant or a removable option may be more appropriate, particularly if the neighbouring teeth are intact. If a bridge is a good fit, we’ll explain material options, preparation, expected maintenance, and how to keep the margins healthy with daily cleaning.
bullets: Careful assessment of bite, bone levels, and supporting teeth
Options across conventional, cantilever, and resin-bonded designs
Digital planning to balance fit, contact points, and cleaning access
Clear maintenance plan so the bridge remains comfortable

sections.eyebrow: When a dental bridge may be suitable
sections.title: When a dental bridge may be suitable
items: A bridge may be considered when a tooth is missing and the neighbouring teeth can support a replacement.
In some cases, a bridge is chosen for practical reasons, including speed, suitability, or preference for a fixed option.
However, bridges are not right for everyone. The condition of the supporting teeth and gums matters, as does the bite and the long-term outlook.
We’ll explain why a bridge is being recommended — and what alternatives exist.

sections.title: Dental bridges
sections.body:
A dental bridge is a way of replacing one or more missing teeth by attaching a false tooth to neighbouring teeth.

A bridge can restore appearance and function, but it needs careful planning so it’s comfortable and predictable over the long term.

We’ll assess your teeth, gums, and bite and explain whether a bridge is suitable or whether other options may be more appropriate. Planning a bridge involves weighing up tooth health, bite forces, cleaning access, and long-term predictability.
bullets: Assessment of teeth, gums, and bite before recommending a bridge
Planning focused on comfort, fit, and long-term maintainability
Explanation of alternatives where a bridge may not be suitable

sections.title: Types of dental bridge
items: There are different types of bridge, and the most appropriate option depends on the teeth involved and how they are being supported.
We’ll explain what type is being recommended, why it suits your situation, and what to expect in day-to-day life.

sections.eyebrow: How we plan and fit a bridge
sections.title: Measured steps to protect the supporting teeth
items: Comprehensive exam with scans and bite assessment to confirm suitability
Discussion of options versus implants or dentures, including pros, limits, and maintenance
Conservative preparation or enamel conditioning on the supporting teeth where required
Digital impressions and photographs to guide the lab design and shade
Try-in or fit appointment with careful seating, contact checks, and occlusal adjustments
Review visit to confirm comfort, hygiene technique, and long-term care plan

sections.label: Digital accuracy
sections.title: Scans that shape fit, bite, and hygiene access
sections.body: Intraoral scanning records the prepared teeth, opposing bite, and soft tissue profile. The data helps the lab design pontics with natural emergence profiles and retainers that seat smoothly, reducing chairside adjustments and protecting the gums.

sections.title: Aftercare and maintenance
items: Bridges need good daily cleaning and regular review to remain healthy and comfortable.
Cleaning around and under a bridge is different from cleaning natural teeth, and we’ll show you practical ways to do this.
Regular reviews help us monitor the supporting teeth and gums and address any issues early.

faqs.question: Do bridges look natural?
faqs.answer: We match shade and shape so a bridge sits neatly alongside neighbouring teeth. We’ll explain what is realistic for your smile and bite.

faqs.question: How long do bridges last?
faqs.answer: Longevity varies and depends on the condition of the supporting teeth, bite forces, and how well the bridge can be cleaned.

faqs.question: Will it feel strange at first?
faqs.answer: It can take a short adjustment period. We’ll check comfort and bite and make refinements if needed.

faqs.question: Can I eat normally?
faqs.answer: Most patients return to normal eating once the bridge is settled. We’ll give guidance on what to avoid while you adapt.

faqs.question: Are implants an alternative?
faqs.answer: Yes. Implants are an alternative for some patients, and we’ll explain the benefits and limitations alongside bridges.
